block.p: COLLEGE BASKETBALL
COLLEGE BASKETBALL
Providence Staves Off Boston College
Providence was hot from outside; Boston College couldn't miss from the line. It doesn't take a math major to figure out who is going to win a trade of 1-pointers for 3-pointers.
Derrick Brown and Michael Brown combined for 43 points and eight of the Friars' 14 3-pointers last night as Providence held off No. 21 Boston College, 76-75, in Newton, Mass.

Providence (11-7 over all, 4-6 in the Big East) went 9 of 10 from 3-point range in the second half to beat the Eagles (12-5, 5-4) for the fourth consecutive time, the seventh in eight games. It was the Friars' first victory over a ranked team in four attempts this season. (AP)

SYRACUSE 72, MIAMI 51: Otis Hill and John Wallace pounded Miami inside for a combined 36 points and No. 18 Syracuse harassed the Hurricanes into 30 percent shooting. It was the second straight blowout loss for Miami (10-8, 4-6 Big East), which lost by 28 to Villanova on Saturday. Syracuse (15-6, 6-5) avenged a 75-66 loss to Miami earlier this year. (AP)

MEMPHIS 83, DePAUL 82: In Rosemont, Ill., Mingo Johnson scored 6 points in overtime as No. 11 Memphis (16-3, 7-1 Conference USA) withstood DePaul's second-half surge, sending the Blue Demons (7-12, 0-8) to their school-record ninth straight loss. (AP)

MARYLAND 80, VIRGINIA 72: In Charlottesville, Va., Keith Booth scored 11 of his career-high 27 points during a 17-2 run when Maryland (10-7, 3-4 Atlantic Coast Conference) took command, handing Virginia (7-10, 2-6) its fifth straight loss. (AP)

UTAH 77, TEXAS-EL PASO 62: In Salt Lake City, Brandon Jessie and Keith Van Horn scored 17 points each to lead No. 7 Utah (17-3, 9-1 Western Athletic Conference) to a victory over Texas-El Paso (10-9, 2-8). (AP)

WASHINGTON 80, ARIZONA 79: Jason Hartman made a free throw with 1.1 seconds left in overtime, lifting Washington (13-4, 6-2 Pac-10) to its first victory in Tucson in 12 years over No. 14 Arizona (15-4, 5-3). (AP)
TENNIS
Seles Gains Despite Ailing Shoulder

Top-seeded Monica Seles, in obvious distress because of an aching shoulder, defeated Irina Spirlea of Romania, 6-4, 6-2, yesterday and led the way into the quarterfinals of the Toray Pan Pacific Open in Tokyo. Eighth-seeded Lindsay Davenport also advanced by beating another American, Lisa Raymond, 6-1, 6-3.
Seles, a left-hander, several times rubbed her left shoulder with her right hand during breaks in the 65-minute match.

Seles won her fourth Australian Open women's singles title last Saturday. In today's quarterfinals, she takes on seventh-seeded Iva Majoli of Croatia, who eliminated Brenda Schultz-McCarthy of the Netherlands, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. (AP)
N.H.L.
Flyers Edge Canadiens in Overtime

Eric Desjardins scored from the right circle with 29.8 seconds remaining in overtime last night as the Philadelphia Flyers beat Montreal, 3-2. Shjon Podein scrambled for the puck behind the Canadiens' net and spotted Desjardins coming down from the point. Desjardins ripped a shot that got by goaltender Pat Jablonski for his fifth goal of the season. The loss snapped Montreal's four-game winning streak. (AP)

BRUINS 2, PANTHERS 2: Jody Hull knocked a rebound past Bill Ranford at 11:15 of the third period and John Vanbiesbrouck stopped four Boston shots in overtime as the Bruins and Florida played to a tie. (AP)
CAPITALS 4, SENATORS 2: Dale Hunter scored the game-winner midway through the third period as Washington overcame a two-goal deficit to beat host Ottawa. (AP)
BLUES 2, CANUCKS 2: Alexander Mogilny had one apparent goal waved off in the final minute of regulation, then scored with 7.9 seconds to go to give Vancouver a tie in St. Louis. (AP)
